title: Pretty little CLIs
description: How to make a gorgeous command line interface in R using the cli package.
contents:
If you‚Äôve been working in R for any length of time, you‚Äôve probably realised that you sometimes need to write code that prints information to the R console, and if you‚Äôre like me you‚Äôve learned that the simplest way to do this is to use the cat() function. Perhaps you find yourself writing code like this: wait <- function(seconds = 2) {Sys.sleep(seconds)} simple_message <- function() { cat("Dead girls walking.") wait() cat(" --A.\n") } simple_message() The ominous text messages used in this post are taken from the TV show Pretty Little Liars In a realistic example, the wait() function would likely be something that takes some time to complete, and the lines above and below are a polite way to let your user (even if that‚Äôs just you!) know when the waiting process starts and when it finishes. In any case, when you source a script containing this code, the first part of the message will appear on the console immediately: Dead girls walking. Then after a two second delay, the console updates to reveal that the author of the threatening message is the mysterious ‚ÄúA.‚Äù character: Dead girls walking. --A. It‚Äôs not too difficult to imagine what this looks like in the console, but courtesy of the asciicast package (Cs√°rdi et al. 2019), there‚Äôs no need to leave anything to the imagination: This approach works perfectly well for simple text communication, but sometimes you want something that looks a little nicer. After all, if you‚Äôre planning to impersonate a dead teenager and terrorise her friends using R, you might as well put a little effort into the details, right? Meet the cli package If you‚Äôve worked in the tidyverse (Wickham et al. 2019) for any length of time you will have noticed that messages produced by tidyverse packages seem to have a more polished look to them. Perhaps, like me, you‚Äôve wondered how the magic works and if you too can create pretty messages at the console. As it happens, many wonderful things become possible if you happen to have the cli package (Cs√°rdi 2021) as your talented assistant, and in this post I‚Äôll talk about some of them. To craft a beautiful command line interface (CLI) of our very own, the first thing we‚Äôll need to do is load the package: library(cli) The design of cli separates style from structure: your messaging code specifies the structure associated with the message, not the superficial style. The cli_h1() command generates a ‚Äútop-level‚Äù heading, the cli_h2() command generates a second level heading, cli_text()inserts basic, and so on. So the code you write might look something like this: title_theme <- function() { cli_h1("Secret, by The Pierces") cli_text("Got a secret, can you keep it?") cli_text("Swear this one you'll save") cli_text("Better lock it in your pocket") cli_text("Taking this one to the grave") cli_text("If I show you then I know you won't tell what I said") cli_text("Cause two can keep a secret if one of them is dead") } title_theme() When this code is executed, the cli package applies the appropriate styling to create the actual output. You can customise this style using the theming system in cli, but I‚Äôve never felt a need to do so because the default theme is rather nice: Sometimes you may prefer send the user short alert messages. You can create generic alerts with cli_alert() or you could be more specific by using cli_alert_info(), cli_alert_warning(), cli_alert_danger(), cli_alert_success(). Most of the text messages sent by A. in Pretty Little Liars were quite threatening, so in this case it might be more appropriate to mark it as one: threatening_text <- function() { cli({ cli_alert_warning("The truth won't set you free, bitches.") cli_alert_warning("I'm going to bury you with it.") cli_alert_warning("Kisses") cli_alert_warning("-A") }) } threatening_text() Note that I wrapped it in a call to cli(): this has the effect of telling R to group all these as a single message, and in doing so makes sure that they aren‚Äôt ever displayed separately. Often that‚Äôs what you want, but not necessarily. For example, most of the time there‚Äôs some code in between each message that takes some time to execute. If we wanted the title theme to reveal itself gradually, scrolling up the screen as it does title_theme_scroll <- function() { cli_h1("Secret, by The Pierces"); wait() cli_text("Got a secret, can you keep it?"); wait() cli_text("Swear this one you'll save"); wait() cli_text("Better lock it in your pocket"); wait() cli_text("Taking this one to the grave"); wait() cli_text("If I show you then I know you won't tell what I said"); wait() cli_text("Cause two can keep a secret if one of them is dead"); wait() } title_theme_scroll() The theme song is Secrets, the first track from the 2007 album Thirteen Tales of Love and Revenge by The Pierces Using the status bar In this instance, the output happens to be identical to our first example: all it does is print the lyrics to the music in the title credits from Pretty Little Liars, with a brief pause between each line. However the R console has many dark secrets, and fancier tricks than this are possible once you know a few‚Ä¶ message_scroll <- function() { cli_text("You found my bracelet."); wait() cli_text("Now come find me."); wait() cli_text("Good luck bitches."); wait() cli_text("-A"); wait() } message_scroll() message_inline <- function() { id <- cli_status("") cli_status_update(id, "You found my bracelet."); wait() cli_status_update(id, "Now come find me."); wait() cli_status_update(id, "Good luck bitches."); wait() cli_status_update(id, "-A"); wait() cli_status_clear(id) } message_inline() Creating spinners theatrics <- function(which) { spinny <- make_spinner( which = which, template = "{spin} It's not over until I say it is." ) for(i in 1:100) { spinny$spin() wait(.05) } spinny$finish() cli_alert_success("Sleep tight while you still can, bitches. -A") } theatrics("dots2") There are quite a few possible spinners list_spinners() [1] "dots" "dots2" "dots3" [4] "dots4" "dots5" "dots6" [7] "dots7" "dots8" "dots9" [10] "dots10" "dots11" "dots12" [13] "line" "line2" "pipe" [16] "simpleDots" "simpleDotsScrolling" "star" [19] "star2" "flip" "hamburger" [22] "growVertical" "growHorizontal" "balloon" [25] "balloon2" "noise" "bounce" [28] "boxBounce" "boxBounce2" "triangle" [31] "arc" "circle" "squareCorners" [34] "circleQuarters" "circleHalves" "squish" [37] "toggle" "toggle2" "toggle3" [40] "toggle4" "toggle5" "toggle6" [43] "toggle7" "toggle8" "toggle9" [46] "toggle10" "toggle11" "toggle12" [49] "toggle13" "arrow" "arrow2" [52] "arrow3" "bouncingBar" "bouncingBall" [55] "smiley" "monkey" "hearts" [58] "clock" "earth" "moon" [61] "runner" "pong" "shark" [64] "dqpb" theatrics("hearts") Showing cli messages in R markdown This doesn‚Äôt work cli_alert("I'm still here bitches, and I know everything. -A") It throws an obscure error message that includes something like this1 PCDATA invalid Char value... sanitise_ansi<- function(x, options) { paste0( "
",
    fansi::sgr_to_html(x = x, warn = FALSE, term.cap = "256"),
    "
" ) } knitr::knit_hooks$set(output = sanitise_ansi) But this does cli_alert("I'm still here bitches, and I know everything. -A") ‚Üí I'm still here bitches, and I know everything. -A Well sort of‚Ä¶ cli_blockquote( quote = "Friends share secrets, that's what keeps us close", citation = "Alison" ) ‚ÄúFriends share secrets, that's what keeps us close‚Äù ‚Äî Alison I should have had this set too options(crayon.enabled = TRUE) cli_blockquote( quote = "Popular in life and death", citation = "Spencer" ) ‚ÄúPopular in life and death‚Äù ‚Äî Spencer Cs√°rdi, G√°bor. 2021. Cli: Helpers for Developing Command Line Interfaces. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=cli. Cs√°rdi, G√°bor, Romain Francois, Mario Nebl, and Marcin Kulik. 2019. Asciicast: Create ‚ÄôAscii‚Äô Screen Casts from R Scripts. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=asciicast. Wickham, Hadley, Mara Averick, Jennifer Bryan, Winston Chang, Lucy D‚ÄôAgostino McGowan, Romain Fran√ßois, Garrett Grolemund, et al. 2019. ‚ÄúWelcome to the tidyverse.‚Äù Journal of Open Source Software 4 (43): 1686. https://doi.org/10.21105/joss.01686. If you‚Äôre running a distill site with an RSS feed it may also write malformed characters into the index.xml file. Even after fixing the errors in my .Rmd file I had to delete the index.xml file and then rebuild.‚Ü©Ô∏é

title: Welcome to the jungle
description:
I have reluctantly decided to create a new blog. Some thoughts on 
what I hope to achieve, having tried my hand at blogging so very many times 
before
contents:
I‚Äôve decided the time has come to restart my blog. I‚Äôve tried blogging many times before with mixed success, and this time around I‚Äôd like to avoid the mistakes of the past. I‚Äôve set up this blog with a few principles in mind:
Simplicity. One mistake I‚Äôve often made is to create blogs using the fanciest tools I could find. For example, I‚Äôve previously used Hugo based packages like blogdown and hugodown, and much as I love those tools (and use them on other sites) I want this blog to be as low-maintenance as possible. To that end I‚Äôm using distill for R markdown, and I‚Äôm keeping the default settings in most respects.
Encapsulation. There was a time when I really liked the idea of having my blog integrated nicely with my homepage (djnavarro.net). I‚Äôve become less keen on this because the aesthetic and technical demands of a blog aren‚Äôt always aligned with the needs of my homepage. This time I‚Äôve set it up so that the blog.djnavarro.net subdomain corresponds to a different repository from my homepage. I‚Äôm hoping this will make blogging simpler from a technical standpoint.
Focus. Another mistake I have made in the past is letting blogs ‚Äúsprawl‚Äù, mixing personal essays with technical posts. My intention with this blog is to write technical posts only, mostly on R and data science. I‚Äôve moved my personal writing to essays.djnavarro.net and my artwork to art.djnavarro.net. My hope is that this will make blogging easier from an emotional standpoint.
Reproducibility. A frustration I‚Äôve had with my previous blogs is that my posts were not particularly reproducible. Source code was often missing, information about the R session was not provided, and so on. This time, I‚Äôve set up the blog so that there is a ‚Äúdetails‚Äù section at the bottom of each post containing links to the source code, the R session information, and a lockfile generated using renv::snapshot().
At this stage I‚Äôm not entirely certain how I‚Äôll use the blog. There are a lot of possibilities, and I have some thoughts on which ones I‚Äôd like to explore. A self-contained blog such as this seems nicely suited to teaching materials. An obvious example would be to write blog posts to accompany the data science slides and youtube videos I‚Äôve been making. The lack of written material to go with those talks has bothered me for some time. Another possibility might be to write tutorials on generative art. I use my art website to post the art itself, but the site functions as a gallery rather than a classroom. I get a lot of people asking questions about how I make my art, and this blog might be a good place to provide answers. Those aren‚Äôt the only possibilities, of course, but they are appealing ones.
Not sure how this will go, but fingers crossed! ü§û
